Input.threadtitle: Reason cannot be the master
Input.posts:
David Hume writes 'Reason is and ought only to be the slave of the passions' Does Hume derive an 'ought' from an 'is'? I don't think that's accurate. If you read further (or in this case, slightly earlier) he lays out the claim that all of our moral decisions are no more or less logical than any others, including even the notion of causing myself more or less good. So, in a way, he derives an 'ought' from a 'cannot be otherwise'. This, I believe, is inevitably true for our withstanding definition of logic or reason. Since reason is a way of analysis, it has no steering power of its own. That is to say, the ideas 'murder is good' and 'murder is bad' are logically equivalent, and our choice of one idea over another is entirely unreasonable. It is only once we've established a purpose, or alternatively defined which things fit on either side of a scale, that we can use reason to our benefit. In fact, I would go further, and claim that reason is, and can only be, a tool of deconstruction. This deconstruction is crucial to us, for without it we cannot tell one thing from another, and our view becomes very clouded. However, it can never, by itself, account for much more than Descartes' 'I think therefore I am', let alone define the goal we should pursue. A great heretic to this belief is Emanuel Kant, who offered his 'Categorical Imperative' as a purely reasonable form of ethical thought. He argues that moral actions are those that could be generalized as a rule for all of humanity, and if it would contradict itself when generalized in such a way, it is morally wrong. However, I believe his idea falls short, not only in that it is derived, as any idea, from something other than reason (there is no logical reason to assume that there is such a rule in the first place), but also it is logically inconsistent. (There is no reason to assume a contradiction when generalized applies to any specific case) On a side note, Robert M. Pirsig, in his book 'Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance', lays out the claim that even scientific progress is not purely logical. Rather, you use logic to analyze a problem, but there is no logical procedure of coming up with a hypothesis. Simply put, hypotheses are brought forth by means of something other than logic. Science differs from other fields of life only in that hypotheses are subject to dismissal if they fail logical deconstruction or experimental disproof. In short, all moral thought begins without reason. Thus, I agree completely with David Hume that 'Reason is, and ought only to be, the slave of the passions'

Does Utilitarianism make an argument for peeping toms being moral? Assume there is a 'peeping tom' (person who gets sexual pleasure by hiding and observing people have sex or get undressed) who is very good at never getting caught in the act. To the ones being viewed, there is no difference in their lives- they don't think anyone is viewing them and treat their lives the same way. The peeing tom gains sexual pleasure. Since this action is benefiting the peeping tom and not effecting those being peeped, is the peeping tom being moral from a utilitarian standpoint? Is it only immoral if the peeping tom is caught?

Timothy, my understanding is that as per Classical Utilitarianism you are right. All malicious pleasures are also considered good. Jeremy Bentham (Classical Utilitarian) argued that an action is not intrinsically wrong or right ; it can be judged only by its impact. If it creates pleasure or reduces pain, it is good. He did not attach any weight to issues like “unnatural acts”, “acts which go against liberty or a person’s freedom” etc. The 'hedonistic' act you describe wold therefore qualify as giving pleasure to the peeping tom and therefore be a good act. This is precisely why there is objection to this argument - it ignores 'intent'. Motive for actions is also an important consideration. To quote one such Philosopher - Moore ' The pleasures of sadists, in virtue of their desires to harm others, get discounted — they are not good, even though they are pleasures.” I think, Kant also puts intention before the consequences of the action.

According to the Utilitarian model, the potential harms and benefits of an action for all concerned must be identified and compared impartially in order to determine whether the action is morally right or wrong. If the potential harms outweigh the expected benefits, the act is morally wrong. If the expected benefits outweigh the potential harms, the act is morally right. Peeping Toms are invading others' privacy. It is no different than if someone were to read your private emails and private letters. A utilitarian would most likely present arguments that attempt to establish privacy as an universal value necessarily connected to important moral features like dignity or well-being. For a utilitarian, it is necessary means to an end.

Thanks! That's funny. I was actually just studying Kosslyn's book, 'The Case For Mental Imagery', without realizing he was perhaps the co-author of this passage I had lying around. Input.threadtitle: Did Plato Forget To Consider the Cave Citizens?

What about the prisoners themselves? Plato says nothing about their being dumb. Being human, wouldn't they talk to each other? Could we assume that each individual contains within him or herself a 'reality' actually much deeper even than a statue or urn? Is that reality deeper, even, than sky or tree? Let's face it, even up here on the surface, vision is fallible. Even the puppeteers don't get the whole picture.

Input.threadtitle: Did Plato Forget To Consider the Cave Citizens?
Input.posts:
Just dabbling in the Allegory of the Cave, and it occurs to me that the fire and the 'movers & shakers' manning the artifacts aren't the only realities in the room, so to speak. What about the prisoners themselves? Plato says nothing about their being dumb. Being human, wouldn't they talk to each other? And wouldn't they gain real, true understanding of another human through that interaction (knowledge!). Could we assume that each individual contains within him or herself a 'reality' actually much deeper even than a statue or urn? Is that reality deeper, even, than sky or tree? Let's face it, even up here on the surface, vision is fallible. Even the puppeteers don't get the whole picture.

And in the cave, the shadows on the wall are not real objects, but the projections of them - so everything the prisoners discuss is through words for things that don't exist. On the other hand, if the cave society is close to our own (and Plato hints that it is, given that someone could escape and ultimately make sense of what they're seeing), then relationships inside the cave might be like relationships inside the Matrix. Neo has conversations and relationships with people inside the matrix even if, when he wakes up, he realises that all the cars, buildings, and even the weather never really existed.

Input.threadtitle: Metaphysics (what is it good for?) or why our experience of snakes DOES reveal something true about snakes
Input.posts:
Professor Holbo, as I watched this week's delightful lectures, I couldn't help but feel a bit confused when trying to grasp certain ideas you seem to propose, which in turn led me to consider what is the meaning and interest of metaphysics at all. You seem to think that studying areas in our brains that make us quite adept at recognizing snakes says nothing about 'snakes' themselves. I could not disagree more. Let's assume, for our purposes, that natural selection is a scientific fact in the world we experience. In that case, imagine a species X that is lethally susceptible to some characteristic A of species Y. Both X and Y live in the same region and cannot avoid meeting. Any member of species X that misrepresented elements A (or others) of species Y (e.g. due to poor sensory inputs or just ignoring the power of A) would have an increased probability to die from A, in relation to the individuals that were particularly suited to deal with Y. Over time, in a population, only X members that easily dealt with Y would survive. Such are humans (X) and snakes (Y). If the way humans perceive snakes did not say anything true and meaningful about the real material nature of snakes, we would all be dead by now because our ancestors wouldn't have made it in the wild. This is a trivial true, and denying it is the same as denying natural selection. Then comes the Platonist answer - and yours, if I understood you correctly. The 'snakeness' in the snake is an ideal concept, and it is what makes it a snake. We experience some things of the snake, but they are not enough to paint the whole picture because in our world we have only access to some details. Sure, I won't dispute this (although I think to postulate such a complex and esoteric idea, without facts or evidence for it, just to fit a metaphysical theory, is precisely why people turn away from philosophy). What I dispute is the assumption that those details we access can be totally different or even distinct from 'snakeness'. Whatever we're looking at, it has to be a partial portrait of what it means to be a real sneakey-snake: or to put it another way, the shadows we are looking at in the cave are a realistic depiction of whatever's causing it. Plato's cave is more like a 3D movie than caveman fiction. You see where I'm getting at: obviously this seems like a ridiculous discussion about snakes, but the same could be said about ethics or mathematics. The way we 'do' ethics does say something fundamentally true about what ethics really is; thus no ethical theory can ignore our intuitions and feelings about what is the ethical thing to do. Ethics is, in a way, within us - it is the result of millions of years of social beings somewhat like us trying to come up with ways of being decent to each other that worked. Even if you believe Plato's metaphysics, it follows from natural selection that the projections are not independent from the reality causing them, and empirical inquiry does reveal something fundamental about the World (which means the way we see and experience snakes does say something - just not all - true about snakes themselves). The only way of opposing this view is to postulate that we're not living in Plato's cave, but rather in the Matrix. We're brains in vats, and all our reality is being artificially produced by some great machine. The world we experience may be consistent, but its internal consistency is artificial: natural selection itself only works in this world because someone programmed it; true ethics is some ethereal concepts that bears no resemblance to our artificial intuitions in this world. Fair enough (let me punch the wall while I come to grips with the fact that some people seriously believe this). This last paragraph is impossible to disprove - you can never prove a negative, even more so in metaphysics. I can only say that even if you believe this you have to admit that for all practical purposes what we care about is the consistency of our made-up world - and regarding those things with existence in our made-up world, we do have access to something true (in this artificial universe). So even in that case my conclusion seems to hold, at least as an operational, pragmatic principle. Ultimately, this leads me to consider why metaphysics is important at all. Metaphysics is basically the activity of postulating ultimate causes to simple facts that can be explained otherwise, without quoting facts or providing evidence, and in such a way that whatever metaphysical theory you conjure can never be disproven. As we know from the beautiful field of theology, doing so can sometimes have quite disastrous consequences. The best we can do is try to show how diminished the probability that metaphysical theories are true, and, as I tried to do here, propose that we don't need them to explain the world. Of course I may have misinterpreted you, or I may be wrong. Looking forward to your comments!

Instructor's Post
Hi Ricardo, I think I was probably unclear so let me just clarify. The unclear part is this: you can't learn anything about snakes by studying brainscans of people looking at snakes. In a sense, you can learn about snakes by studying us (so that was unclear). Example: if you didn't know it already, you could reasonably infer that we and those snakes have a long history together. The fact that we react to them so dramatically suggests that we have adapted to react to them, which suggests we shared an ancient environment. So, if we didn't know before (which we actually did, but we might not have) you could make reasonable inferences about snakes themselves, their ecology, etc. What I meant to get at was more like: snakes exist anyway (whether we think so or not, whether we perceive them or not). That is, they aren't mind-dependent. They existed before we humans showed up and if we went away, they would continue to exist, independent of our now non-existent perceptions of them. I don't think they are 'in' our brains - or minds - in such a way that if our brains - or minds - didn't exist they wouldn't. George Berkeley didn't agree. But I think most people should agree. Some people will complain that what I just said is naive realism. I think it's more like moderate naturalism, and I'm pretty sure it would be shared by Lakoff and Nunez. (It's not unproblematic but I think it's more or less agreeable to a lot of people.) By contrast, Lakoff and Nunez are sort of committed to the proposition that, if we humans ceased to exist, math would cease to exist. Because math comes from our brains. No brains, nothing for math to come from. No math. Their argument was: cognitive science of mathematics wouldn't be interesting if mathematics were brain independent. But cognitive science of mathematics is interesting. Ergo, mathematics can't be brain independent. My point was: the same goes for snakes. Snake neurons are interesting! But that doesn't mean snakes aren't mind independent. Does that help?

Input.posts:
Professor Holbo, as I watched this week's delightful lectures, I couldn't help but feel a bit confused when trying to grasp certain ideas you seem to propose, which in turn led me to consider what is the meaning and interest of metaphysics at all. You seem to think that studying areas in our brains that make us quite adept at recognizing snakes says nothing about 'snakes' themselves. I could not disagree more. Let's assume, for our purposes, that natural selection is a scientific fact in the world we experience. In that case, imagine a species X that is lethally susceptible to some characteristic A of species Y. Both X and Y live in the same region and cannot avoid meeting. Any member of species X that misrepresented elements A (or others) of species Y (e.g. due to poor sensory inputs or just ignoring the power of A) would have an increased probability to die from A, in relation to the individuals that were particularly suited to deal with Y. Over time, in a population, only X members that easily dealt with Y would survive. Such are humans (X) and snakes (Y). If the way humans perceive snakes did not say anything true and meaningful about the real material nature of snakes, we would all be dead by now because our ancestors wouldn't have made it in the wild. This is a trivial true, and denying it is the same as denying natural selection. Then comes the Platonist answer - and yours, if I understood you correctly. The 'snakeness' in the snake is an ideal concept, and it is what makes it a snake. We experience some things of the snake, but they are not enough to paint the whole picture because in our world we have only access to some details. Sure, I won't dispute this (although I think to postulate such a complex and esoteric idea, without facts or evidence for it, just to fit a metaphysical theory, is precisely why people turn away from philosophy). What I dispute is the assumption that those details we access can be totally different or even distinct from 'snakeness'. Whatever we're looking at, it has to be a partial portrait of what it means to be a real sneakey-snake: or to put it another way, the shadows we are looking at in the cave are a realistic depiction of whatever's causing it. Plato's cave is more like a 3D movie than caveman fiction. You see where I'm getting at: obviously this seems like a ridiculous discussion about snakes, but the same could be said about ethics or mathematics. The way we 'do' ethics does say something fundamentally true about what ethics really is; thus no ethical theory can ignore our intuitions and feelings about what is the ethical thing to do. Ethics is, in a way, within us - it is the result of millions of years of social beings somewhat like us trying to come up with ways of being decent to each other that worked. Even if you believe Plato's metaphysics, it follows from natural selection that the projections are not independent from the reality causing them, and empirical inquiry does reveal something fundamental about the World (which means the way we see and experience snakes does say something - just not all - true about snakes themselves). The only way of opposing this view is to postulate that we're not living in Plato's cave, but rather in the Matrix. We're brains in vats, and all our reality is being artificially produced by some great machine. The world we experience may be consistent, but its internal consistency is artificial: natural selection itself only works in this world because someone programmed it; true ethics is some ethereal concepts that bears no resemblance to our artificial intuitions in this world. Fair enough (let me punch the wall while I come to grips with the fact that some people seriously believe this). This last paragraph is impossible to disprove - you can never prove a negative, even more so in metaphysics. I can only say that even if you believe this you have to admit that for all practical purposes what we care about is the consistency of our made-up world - and regarding those things with existence in our made-up world, we do have access to something true (in this artificial universe). So even in that case my conclusion seems to hold, at least as an operational, pragmatic principle. Ultimately, this leads me to consider why metaphysics is important at all. Metaphysics is basically the activity of postulating ultimate causes to simple facts that can be explained otherwise, without quoting facts or providing evidence, and in such a way that whatever metaphysical theory you conjure can never be disproven. As we know from the beautiful field of theology, doing so can sometimes have quite disastrous consequences. The best we can do is try to show how diminished the probability that metaphysical theories are true, and, as I tried to do here, propose that we don't need them to explain the world. Of course I may have misinterpreted you, or I may be wrong. Looking forward to your comments!

Input.posts:
Professor Holbo, as I watched this week's delightful lectures, I couldn't help but feel a bit confused when trying to grasp certain ideas you seem to propose, which in turn led me to consider what is the meaning and interest of metaphysics at all. You seem to think that studying areas in our brains that make us quite adept at recognizing snakes says nothing about 'snakes' themselves. I could not disagree more. Let's assume, for our purposes, that natural selection is a scientific fact in the world we experience. In that case, imagine a species X that is lethally susceptible to some characteristic A of species Y. Both X and Y live in the same region and cannot avoid meeting. Any member of species X that misrepresented elements A (or others) of species Y (e.g. due to poor sensory inputs or just ignoring the power of A) would have an increased probability to die from A, in relation to the individuals that were particularly suited to deal with Y. Over time, in a population, only X members that easily dealt with Y would survive. Such are humans (X) and snakes (Y). If the way humans perceive snakes did not say anything true and meaningful about the real material nature of snakes, we would all be dead by now because our ancestors wouldn't have made it in the wild. This is a trivial true, and denying it is the same as denying natural selection. Then comes the Platonist answer - and yours, if I understood you correctly. The 'snakeness' in the snake is an ideal concept, and it is what makes it a snake. We experience some things of the snake, but they are not enough to paint the whole picture because in our world we have only access to some details. Sure, I won't dispute this (although I think to postulate such a complex and esoteric idea, without facts or evidence for it, just to fit a metaphysical theory, is precisely why people turn away from philosophy). What I dispute is the assumption that those details we access can be totally different or even distinct from 'snakeness'. Whatever we're looking at, it has to be a partial portrait of what it means to be a real sneakey-snake: or to put it another way, the shadows we are looking at in the cave are a realistic depiction of whatever's causing it. Plato's cave is more like a 3D movie than caveman fiction. You see where I'm getting at: obviously this seems like a ridiculous discussion about snakes, but the same could be said about ethics or mathematics. The way we 'do' ethics does say something fundamentally true about what ethics really is; thus no ethical theory can ignore our intuitions and feelings about what is the ethical thing to do. Ethics is, in a way, within us - it is the result of millions of years of social beings somewhat like us trying to come up with ways of being decent to each other that worked. Even if you believe Plato's metaphysics, it follows from natural selection that the projections are not independent from the reality causing them, and empirical inquiry does reveal something fundamental about the World (which means the way we see and experience snakes does say something - just not all - true about snakes themselves). The only way of opposing this view is to postulate that we're not living in Plato's cave, but rather in the Matrix. We're brains in vats, and all our reality is being artificially produced by some great machine. The world we experience may be consistent, but its internal consistency is artificial: natural selection itself only works in this world because someone programmed it; true ethics is some ethereal concepts that bears no resemblance to our artificial intuitions in this world. Fair enough (let me punch the wall while I come to grips with the fact that some people seriously believe this). This last paragraph is impossible to disprove - you can never prove a negative, even more so in metaphysics. I can only say that even if you believe this you have to admit that for all practical purposes what we care about is the consistency of our made-up world - and regarding those things with existence in our made-up world, we do have access to something true (in this artificial universe). So even in that case my conclusion seems to hold, at least as an operational, pragmatic principle. Ultimately, this leads me to consider why metaphysics is important at all. Metaphysics is basically the activity of postulating ultimate causes to simple facts that can be explained otherwise, without quoting facts or providing evidence, and in such a way that whatever metaphysical theory you conjure can never be disproven. As we know from the beautiful field of theology, doing so can sometimes have quite disastrous consequences. The best we can do is try to show how diminished the probability that metaphysical theories are true, and, as I tried to do here, propose that we don't need them to explain the world. Of course I may have misinterpreted you, or I may be wrong. Looking forward to your comments!
